metadata.case_name: Rambandhu and Ors. v. Sumitra Devi and Anr.

facts.text: Ram Kishori Lal Sao died in September 1927 leaving extensive properties worth several lakhs, including houses in Asansol, businesses at Howrah and Asansol, money in banks and loans.
Sumitra Devi, widow of Ram Kishori Lal, brought Title Suit No. 664 of 1927 against step-sons for partition.

Preliminary decree in partition suit passed on July 22, 1933; final decree on June 29, 1936. Each son got one-sixth share. Sumitra Devi got one-third share (one-sixth as widow, one-sixth as mother of pre-deceased son Lachmi Narain who died January 1, 1936). Her share included four houses on Municipal Holdings Nos. 116, 17, 26, 27 worth about Rs. 19,000.
Partition decree provided Rs. 10,000 for marriage expenses of minor daughter Kamala Devi and Rs. 50/month maintenance until marriage.
Marriage of Kamala Devi settled at Deoghar on Shivratri day in 1938 with Bijoy Kumar Sao, son of Nand Lal Sao.
Marriage performed on May 10, 1938. Dwiragaman/Gowna ceremony in December 1938.
Sumitra Devi executed registered deed of gift of four houses to Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940.

Title Suit No. 2 of 1942 instituted by four sons of Ram Kishori Lal (Kalicharan died during pendency, heirs substituted) against Sumitra Devi (D1) and Kamala Devi (D2) for declaration that gift deed void beyond lifetime of Sumitra Devi and not binding on reversion.
Subordinate Judge, Asansol decreed suit on June 30, 1943.
Calcutta High Court affirmed on April 6, 1950.

Appellants' case: Marriage settlement at Deoghar included promise of gift of four houses (Rs. 20,000) as dowry; sankalpa at marriage accepted by Nand Lal; confirmed at Gowna; possession given soon after; deed executed later due to illness.

Respondents' case: Negotiations at Asansol; no promise of houses; only ornaments Rs. 5,000, Rs. 800 travel, movables from Rs. 10,000; gift collusive, fraudulent, without consideration, no legal necessity; Sumitra had life interest only.

Subordinate Judge findings: Settlement at Deoghar, no promise of houses at settlement or marriage, no possession delivery proved; interest was maintenance grant, no alienation right except reasonable at marriage/Gowna per s.123 TPA; gift not at time, so inoperative beyond life.

High Court findings: Settlement at Deoghar included promise of four houses (not specific houses); no sankalpa at marriage, no confirmation at Gowna, no possession before deed; gift reasonable (about 1/4 of share Rs.73,000); but too late post-1938, not at marriage/Gowna; s.123 TPA governs time.
Parties governed by Benares school of Mitakshara law.
Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force June 17, 1956 during vacation; fresh arguments heard.

legal_issues.text: Is defendant No. 1 competent to make any gift of the properties mentioned in the plaint beyond her lifetime to defendant No. 2?
Is the deed of gift void and inoperative against the plaintiffs beyond the lifetime of defendant No. 1?
Is the deed of gift executed by defendant No. 1 in favour of defendant No. 2 with the alleged collusive and fraudulent allegations binding on the plaintiffs on her death?
Whether Sumitra Devi had absolute right in partition share under Mitakshara (Benares school)?
Whether gift of reasonable portion as marriage dowry in fulfilment of ante-nuptial promise, two years post-marriage, valid under Hindu law?
Effect of s.14 Hindu Succession Act, 1956 on the properties.

petitioner_arguments.text: Findings of fact erroneous: High Court confused witnesses Parasuram Sharma (No.16) with Pashupati Sarkar (No.10); sankalpa at marriage after Sampradan, accepted by Nand Lal, confirmed at Gowna.
Even accepting findings, gift reasonable, in pursuance of ante-nuptial agreement at Deoghar for spiritual benefit, valid under Hindu law; lapse of time immaterial if fulfilling moral obligation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law texts (Mitakshara, Manu); precedents like Churaman Sahu, Ram Sumran Prasad

petitioner_arguments.text: Sumitra Devi had absolute right in partition share.
Under s.14 Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Sumitra or Kamala full owner.

respondent_arguments.text: No ante-nuptial promise of houses; negotiations at Asansol only ornaments Rs.5000, travel Rs.800, movables from Rs.10,000; no sankalpa, no possession; gift collusive to defeat reversioners; Sumitra had life interest/maintenance, no power to gift beyond life without necessity.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law (limited estate); s.123 Transfer of Property Act

respondent_arguments.text: High Court correct to differ from trial court on ante-nuptial based on reliable witness Rai Saheb Jogendra Nath Roy.
s.14(2) HSA excludes restricted estates; donee cannot get larger than donor.

court_reasoning.text: Declined to interfere with factual findings on no sankalpa/verbal gift at marriage despite witness confusion (Parasuram not fully independent, other discrepancies); ante-nuptial promise at Deoghar upheld based on reliable witness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not sufficient to disturb concurrent findings.

court_reasoning.text: Partition share not absolute/stridhan but like inherited property (Debi Mangal Prasad); limited estate, no absolute disposal right.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partition decree preserved corpus for reversioners.

court_reasoning.text: Widow competent to gift reasonable portion (Rs.19,000 reasonable) as marriage dowry fulfilling ante-nuptial promise/spiritual benefit, even 2 years post-marriage; moral/religious obligation continues; s.123 TPA effects transfer but does not limit Hindu law power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principles from precedents: religious duty to marry daughter, pious acts allow reasonable alienation.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide s.14 HSA as gift valid under pre-1956 Hindu law.

holdings.text: Gift deed dated March 10, 1940 by Sumitra Devi to Kamala Devi valid and binding on reversioners.
Ante-nuptial promise of gift as marriage dowry enforceable even post-marriage if reasonable and for spiritual benefit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Debi Mangal Prasad Singh v. Mahadeo Prasad Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Partition share of widow stands on same footing as inherited property, not stridhan.
Widow can gift reasonable portion at Gowna (part of marriage); distinguished on timing but principle applies.
Inherited property not stridhan under Mitakshara.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Singh v. Kunj Behari Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between obligatory religious acts (wider power) and pious observances (reasonable portion).

precedents_cited.case_name: Cossi Naut Bysack v. Hurroo Soondry Dossee
precedents_cited.relevance: Widow can dispose for religious purposes including daughter dowry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Sumran Prasad v. Gobind Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Gift post-marriage fulfilling promise valid if reasonable.
Moral obligation continues post-marriage; gift valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwati Shukul v. Ram Jatan Tewari
precedents_cited.relevance: No hard rule on extent; reasonable for necessity upheld.
Dissentient; did not consider religious/moral obligation.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires registered instrument for gift of immovable property; effects transfer but does not limit Hindu widow's power to alienate for marriage dowry.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective; converts limited estate to full ownership; unnecessary to apply as gift valid under prior Hindu law.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments and decrees of Subordinate Judge (June 30, 1943) and Calcutta High Court (April 6, 1950) set aside; gift deed held valid and binding on reversioners.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that deed of gift dated March 10, 1940 is valid beyond lifetime of Sumitra Devi and binding on reversion.

key_quotes.text: "It is the imperative, religious duty and a moral obligation of a father, mother or other guardian to give a girl in marriage to a suitable husband it is a duty which must be fulfilled to prevent degradation, and direct spiritual benefit is conferred upon the father by such a marriage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle justifying widow's power to gift for daughter's marriage.

key_quotes.text: "Section 123 does not deal with nor does it affect the power of a Hindu widow to make an alienation of a reasonable portion of her husband's estate in favour of the daughter as marriage dowry."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies TPA does not override Hindu law power.

key_quotes.text: "The ante-nuptial promise cannot be regarded as a gift having been made on the occasion of the marriage."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court error corrected by SC.
